text: I couldn’t hold back. Staring into her eyes, I pressed on, “Where exactly is this? Why do you seem so familiar with it?”
Alicia’s brow twitched ever so slightly. Not anger—just the fatigue of someone whose wound has been touched.
“You just said ‘we’ll need it tomorrow’—what are you planning to do?”
Her voice wasn’t loud, yet it was like a clean blade, cutting the topic off completely.
“The most important thing for you right now is to take Lucia back.”
When she said it, she didn’t look at me. Instead, her gaze rested on the fading glow of the formation deeper inside, as if confirming that some “position” hadn’t shifted.
Lucia quickly tugged at my sleeve and whispered, “Innkeeper… let’s go back first. She really shouldn’t be pressed right now.”
I was about to speak again, but Alicia had already turned and taken a step toward the stairs. The step was light, yet it instinctively forced me into silence.
She left no room for explanation, as if pushing me straight out of her world.
